data.title: Move all Emmet commands from core to extension and localize
data.body:
Currently all the emmet commands get routed from the core to the emmet extension.
This was so that when users use `emmet.useNewEmmet` to `false`, we fall back on the old emmet implementation.

In July, all emmet commands will be using the new model and so will be used out of the extension directly

data.title: Additions to "emmet.includeLanguages" require reload
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (7e2937237620501705e4a5276e76726d35a31905, 2017-06-30T05:07:32.086Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch with no `emmet.includeLanguages`
2. Add, e.g., `"emmet.includeLanguages": { "javascript": "javascriptreact" }`
3. Observe: No Emmet proposals are shown in .js files
4. Reload and observe: Emmet proposals are shown in .js files

data.title: Feature Request: Allow working tab to be a draggable file
data.body:
A great feature MS Word & Excel have is the file icon at the top of the said window is draggable into a drop zone for attachments in emails etc. This eliminates the necessity for digging around my hard drive for the files location. 
Code does not have this feature. Please add it for ease of accessibility. 

- VSCode Version:
1.14.0-insider

data.title: Reset JavaScript expression coloring in template expressions
data.body:
Fixes #29866

Adds new rules to standard theme to reset the coloring of expression inside of js/ts template expressions

data.title: Visual Studio Code 1.13.1 only highlights for up to 2079 lines
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 10
- Reproduces without extensions: Yes
extensions installed:
ms-vscode.cpptools,
lukehoban.go

- Steps to Reproduce

1. Open or create a text file with more than 2079 lines, eg: Untitled-1.txt.
2. Make sure there is one word, eg: hello, repeats in more than 2079 lines.
3. Put cursor caret on that repeated word: hello
4. Use Ctrl-F to find the repeated word: hello
5. Check for the repeated word (ubuntu in my screenshots) repeates at line: 2081 

![visual studio 1 13 1 code highlights 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9011764/27748660-d620f90c-5e02-11e7-8ec6-a2bf8673a723.png)
![visual studio 1 13 1 code highlights 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9011764/27748661-d64bd3c0-5e02-11e7-9542-fe0e5b7b0326.png)

data.title: Group search results by root folders
data.body:
This is a work in progress PR to add support for grouping of search results. I am submitting it now since I believe the rest of the work is mostly minor and I'll only getting back to this PR on Monday. So hopefully will get some early feedback.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/187831/27746459-977b6844-5dc7-11e7-816c-fef7166acb2c.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/187831/27746480-a7bdfb0e-5dc7-11e7-9616-15459be2ff38.png)

TODOs:

* [x] Add replace actions. (For follow-up PR)
* [x] Make it works with extraFileResources
* [x] Always display some FileMatches. Currently will not auto-expand repos if many results
* [x] Render FileMatch names for relative to folder.
* [x] Render single folder searches without extra level.
* [x] Create CSS rule `.foldermatch`, rather than reusing `.filematch`.
* [x] Update textual descriptions of results to take into account folders.
* ~~Bug in Tree renderer for auto-expanded children~~

cc @roblourens

data.title: problemPattern endCharacter off by one

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write a problemMatcher for the vala compiler

  ```json 
      {
        "name": "valac",
        "owner": "vala",
        "fileLocation": "absolute",
        "pattern": {
          "regexp": "^(.*):(\\d+)\\.(\\d+)-(\\d+)\\.(\\d+):\\s+(warning|error):\\s+(.*)$",
          "file": 1,
          "line": 2,
          "column": 3,
          "endLine": 4,
          "endColumn": 5,
          "severity": 6,
          "message": 7
        }
      }
  ```

2. Write some vala code with an error and compile it using a task with the problem matcher above.

3. Observe that vscode marks one less character than the vala compiler output. For example, vscode only underlines `va` but the vala compiler underlines `var`.

  ![selection_014](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/963645/27745356-9f50aa6e-5d88-11e7-9c63-4da9ee852c47.png)

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

---

Apparently, the vala compiler considers the end column inclusive while vscode considers it exclusive. It seems reasonable to add a bool parameter to allow handling of both cases.

data.title: Focus not set to input field when creating new file/folder

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.13.1 (1.13.1)
- OS Version: 10.10.5 (14F2411)

Steps to Reproduce:

0. Prerequisites:
    a) focus must be elsewhere than VSCode (in another screen or window)
    b) VSCode must be visible already
1. In VSCode's Explorer column, right-click onto the directory in which you want to create a new file/folder
2. The blank new file/folder is created, the input is available to use, but not focused, thus if the user starts typing right away, it's either still in the previous focused window/application, or nowhere.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Expected: focus should be set/forced into the field of the newly created file/folder, no matter how the file creation was triggered.

data.title: Retain scroll position with two editors on the same file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I searched for open issues with "scroll position". I didn't find one that seemed related to this issue.

- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Linux Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open two editors on the same file. The file should have enough contents that scrolling is necessary.
2. Scroll editor A to the end of the file. Leave editor B scrolled to the top of the file.
3. Add a new line to the file in editor B.

Notice that when lines are added/removed to B, A scrolls accordingly. This defeats the purpose of two editors open on a (typically really long file), which is to work on two places within the file. I scroll editor A to one location of interest, and editor B to another. As long as there's enough scroll length, the editor which didn't receive the edits should maintain its scrolling position. Otherwise, what is scrolled into view will eventually end-up out of view (in the extreme case). Otherwise, it's visually annoying to see the other editor scrolling.

BTW, Sublime Text handles this very nicely.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Feature request: Option to fetch inside VS Code. Use case, when working with multiple remotes.
data.body:
I'm sometimes working with multiple remotes. When that is the case it would be great to be able to handle fetching and merging directly inside VS Code. Instead of having to leave VS Code and go onto manual git cmds on the cmdline.

I hope I have clearly stated my wishes, if not, feel free to hit me up with questions.

Thank you very much.

TECH. INFO:
-------------

VS Code: 1.13.1
OS: Windows 7

data.title: Problem matcher errors are unhelpful

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write a task with a custom problem matcher (which apparently has some issues) as below
1. Try to run it.

*Expected:*
A helpful error message in the output window that tells me what I did wrong.
*Actual:*
~~~
Error: the description doesn't define a valid problem pattern:
{
    "background": {
        "activeOnStart": true,
        "beginsPattern": ".*",
        "endsPattern": ".*"
    }
}
~~~

tasks.json I'm trying:
```json
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "npm",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "showOutput": "always",
    "suppressTaskName": true,
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "compile",
            "isBuildCommand": true,
            "isTestCommand": false,
            "showOutput": "always",
            "args": [ "run", "local:compile", "--", "--watch" ],
            "isBackground": true,
            "problemMatcher": {
                "background": {
                    "activeOnStart": true,
                    "beginsPattern": ".*",
                    "endsPattern": ".*"
                }
            }
        }
    ]
}
```
<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

(this issue isn't about what is specifically wrong with this configuration, but the fact that the error message doesn't help me figure that out. But if anyone wants to point me in the right direction, that'd be good too)

data.title: "Deleted from disk" indicator is removed once any new file event kicks in
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. set `"workbench.editor.closeOnFileDelete": false`
2. open a file
3. delete it externally
4. notice the label changes to "deleted on disk"
5. save any other file

=> state goes back to indicate the file exists on disk

data.title: Setting `$schema` to `null`  crashes the JSON Language Server
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18.1 'Serena'

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open any *.json file
2. Set `"$schema": null,` at the outermost level of the object
3.  Observe in `output` that the server rapidly fails with `TypeError: Cannot read property 'length' of null` and a banner displays saying "The JSON Language Server server crashed 5 times in the last 3 minutes. The server will not be restarted."

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Proposed fix: Microsoft/vscode-json-languageservice#7

data.title: files.autoSave: afterDelay causes distractingly blinking Source Control working indicator

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows 7
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Configure "files.autoSave": "afterDelay", leave the default delay of 1000 ms.
2. Initialize an empty git repository in the current directory
3. Start editing a file, especially not under source control (so that there's no changed files and no git badge counter on the Source Control icon)
4. Observe that about once every 5 seconds or so a clock badge briefly appears on the Source Control icon and, if you have Source Control panel open, the blue dash moves above the commit message field.

![vscode-source-control-annoyance](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/308111/27737578-4adbe786-5db1-11e7-94fb-25a893934196.gif)

Thats pretty annoying and distracting! It's less noticeable if you're editing a file under source control, since that "in progress" icon then doesn't appear out of the blue but replaces the number of changed files. It's also less noticeable when you don't have the source control panel open so there's no blue dash.

The cause is obvious: vscode saves the file you're actively working on every second, after some further delay the git plugin notices that something changed and asks git what exactly (which can be seen in the output console - Git) and while doing that indicates that it's busy.

Maybe just don't do that? Just don't show the busy indicator when routinely rescanning the source folder? And when autofetching too, by the way, if it does that now.

data.title: Status bar background color is not being applied (themes and if explicitly set in settings.json)
data.body:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Update to the latest insider build and either use a theme that sets the statusbar color or explicitly set it in your settings.json. (See below)

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

This started happening with yesterday's daily insider build. Themes are no longer able to set the statusbar background color. I also cannot set the statusbar background color in my settings.json anymore:

"workbench.colorCustomizations": {

Simple issue, more cosmetics than anything, but when using commands such as `Git pull` or `Git push` the sync icon in the status bar should move the same way than when it's clicked on.
